summary: This FBI Director's Morning Briefing summarizes news coverage from February 21, 2019, regarding a federal judge's ruling that U.S. prosecutors, including then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta, violated federal law by concealing a non-prosecution plea agreement with Jeffrey Epstein from his underage victims. The ruling could potentially nullify the agreement and expose Epstein and co-conspirators to new federal charges.

persons.name: Kenneth A. Marra
persons.context: Ruled that federal prosecutors, including Alexander Acosta, broke federal law by concealing the Jeffrey Epstein plea deal from victims.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: U.S. Labor Secretary, former U.S. Attorney in Miami
persons.context: Identified as a federal prosecutor who helped negotiate a non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, giving him and co-conspirators immunity from federal prosecution.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy, politically connected individual who operated an international sex operation recruiting underage girls; received a non-prosecution agreement from prosecutors.

persons.name: Jack Scarola
persons.context: Represented two victims who challenged the non-prosecution agreement; stated the court's ruling could nullify the agreement and subject Epstein and co-conspirators to new federal charges.

persons.name: Chris Cuomo
persons.context: Commented on the irony of Acosta being Labor Secretary given Epstein's involvement in sex trafficking and the deal Acosta helped negotiate.

persons.name: Asha Rangappa
persons.context: Stated Epstein 'definitely got a sweetheart deal' and contrasted the case with President Trump's stated focus on stopping trafficking.

persons.name: Jim Schultz
persons.context: Argued the deal was not a 'sweetheart deal,' noting Epstein received 18 months in prison, had to register as a sex offender, and victims were designated for civil compensation.

events.title: Judge Rules Prosecutors Broke Law in Epstein Case
events.description: U.S. District Judge Kenneth A. Marra rules that federal prosecutors, including Alexander Acosta, violated federal law by concealing a non-prosecution plea agreement with Jeffrey Epstein from his underage victims.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Alexander Acosta, then U.S. Attorney in Miami, helped negotiate a non-prosecution agreement that gave Jeffrey Epstein and his co-conspirators immunity from federal prosecution for sex trafficking offenses.

keyFacts: A federal judge ruled that prosecutors, including then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta, broke federal law by concealing a plea agreement with Jeffrey Epstein from more than 30 of his underage victims.
The ruling could potentially nullify the 2008 non-prosecution agreement, subjecting Epstein and any co-conspirators to new federal charges.
The evidence reviewed by the judge showed Epstein operated an international sex operation recruiting underage girls from Florida and overseas.
The non-prosecution agreement, negotiated by Acosta, gave Epstein and his co-conspirators immunity from federal prosecution instead of prosecuting him under federal sex trafficking laws.

Legal opinions on the deal were divided, with a former FBI agent calling it a 'sweetheart deal' and a former Trump White House lawyer defending it as appropriate given Epstein's 18-month prison term and sex offender registration.
